statement.p: Let A be a symmetric matrix. Explain step by step how to find an orthonormal basis of eigenvectors of A. (Be sure to consider the case when not all eigenvalues of A are distinct).
Let A be a symmetric matrix. Explain step by step how to find an matrix U and a diagonal matrix D such that A = UDU^T and U^T = U\inv.
Let A be a symmetric matrix. Explain step by step how to find a spectral decomposition of A.
Let A be a symmetric matrix. If \lambda is a root of \det(A-\lambda I) of multiplicity k , explain why the null space of A-\lambda I has dimension k.
Let A be a symmetric matrix with eigenvalues \lambda_1, \lambda_2 and the corresponding eigenvectors v1, v2. Assume \lambda_1 = \lambda_2. Explain why v1, v2 are orthogonal.

Let Q: \R^n\to\R be a quadratic form, that is, a function of the form \sum_{i, j=1}^n a_{ij} x_i x_j where a_{ij} are real numbers and x_k is the kth coordinate on \R^n. Explain how to find a symmetric n \times n matrix A such that Q(x)=Ax\cdot x for all x in \R^n.

Let Q(x) = Ax\cdot x where A is a symmetric n \times n matrix with eigenvalues \lambda_1, \ldots , \lambda_n. Explain how to find a change of variables so that Q becomes \lambda_1 {y_1}^2 + \cdots + \lambda_n {y_n}^2).
Let Q(x) = Ax\cdot x where A is a symmetric n \times n matrix. Explain why Q(x) > 0 for every x \neq 0 if and only if every eigenvalue of A is positive.
Let Q(x) = Ax\cdot x where A is a symmetric n \times n matrix. Explain why Q(x) \geq 0 for every x \neq 0 if and only if every eigenvalue of A is nonnegative.

Let Q(x) = Ax\cdot x where A is a symmetric n \times n matrix with eigenvalues \lambda_1, \ldots , \lambda_n and an orthonormal basis of eigenvectors u_1,\ldots, u_n, where Au_i=\lambda_i u_i. What are the maximum and the minimum of the function Q(x)Q(x) under the constrain \|x\|=1? For which x are the the maximum and the minimum attained?

Let A be a symmetric n \times n such that Q_A(x) = Ax\cdot x is positive definite. Explain why the matrix A\inv is invertible and symmetric. Explain why the quadratic form Q_{A\inv}(x) = A\inv x\cdot x is positive definite.
If A and B are symmetric matrices whose eigenvalues are positive, explain why the eigenvalues of A+B are positive.

[MIT OCW] Suppose u is a unit vector in \R^n, so u^T u=1. This problem is about n \times n symmetric matrix H = I - 2uu^T.
Show directly that H^2 = I. Since H=H^T, we now know that H is not only symmetric but also .
One eigenvector for H is u itself. Find the corresponding eigenvalue.
If v is any vector perpendicular to u, show that v is an eigenvector of H and find the eigenvalue. With all these eigenvectors v, that eigenvalue must be repeated how many times? Is H diagonalizable? Why or Why not?
Find the diagonal entries H_{11} and H_{ii} in terms of u_1 \ldots u_n. Add up H_{11} + \ldots + H_{nn} and separately add up the eigenvalues of H.

ol.li: Explicitly, we find H^2=(I-2uu^T)^2=I^2-4uu^T +4uu^T uu^T since uu^T = 1, H^2=I. Since H=H^T, we also have H^T H=1, implying that H is also an orthogonal matrix.

For any vector v orthogonal to u, we have Hv=(I-2uu^T)v=v-2uu^T v=v, so the associated \lambda=1. The orthogonal complement to the space spanned by u has dimension n-1, so there is a basis of (n-1) orthonormal eigenvectors with this eigenvalue. Adding in the eigenvector u, we find that H is diagonalizable.

Since the ith diagonal entry of uu^T is u_i^2, the i diagonal entry of H is H_{ii}=1-2u_i^2. Summing these together gives \sum_{i=1}^n H_{ii}=n-2\sum_{i=1}^n u_i^2=n-2. Adding up the eigenvalues of H also gives \sum \lambda_i=(1)-1+(n-1)(1)=n-2.

statement.p:
[MIT OCW] Suppose A is a positive definite symmetric n \times n matrix.
How do you know that A\inv is also positive definite?
Suppose Q is any orthogonal n \times n matrix. How do you know that QAQ^T = QAQ\inv is positive definite? Which test would you use?
Show that the block matrix B = \mat{A A; A A} is positive semidefinite. How do you know that B is not positive definite?

ol.li: Since a matrix is positive-definite if and only if all its eigenvalues are positive, and since the eigenvalues of A\inv are simply the inverses of the eigenvalues of A, A\inv is also positive definite (inverse of a positive number is positive).

Using the energy test (x^T Ax > 0 for nonzero x), we find that x^T QAQ^T x = (Q^T x)^T A(Q^T x) > 0 for all nonzero x as well (since Q is invertible). Using the positive eigenvalue test, since A is similar to QAQ\inv and similar matrices have the same eigenvalues, QAQ\inv also has all positive eigenvalues.

statement.p: If A is any m \times n matrix with m \gt n, tell me why AA^T cannot be positive definite. Is A^T A always positive definite? (If not, what is the test on A?)

answer.p: AA^T is an m \times m matrix but its rank is not greater than n (all columns of AA^T are combinations of columns of A). Since n \lt m, AA^T is singular. A^T A is positive definite if A has full column rank n (Not always true, A can even be a zero matrix).
